title: Tuesday, 3rd October, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Hi there

PM11:02am

Our daily markets chat thing

PM11:02am

System running ultra slow for me this morning

11:02 am

PM11:02am

And I can't see comments

PM11:02am

Bear with me while i refresh

11:02 am
PM11:03am

And report the matter to the techies

PM11:04am

PM11:04am

PM11:04am

PM11:05am

Coca Cola HBC AG (CCH:LSE): Last: 2,496, down 61 (-2.39%), High: 2,541, Low: 2,480, Volume: 234.15k
11:06 am
BE11:06am

He was signed off as of 15 September, for what was going to be a four-month medical leave of absence.

PM11:06am

Goodness

BE11:06am

Michalis Imellos serving as acting CEO

11:06 am
BE11:07am

Beyond condolences there's not a lot to say here.

BE11:07am

Though Jefferies tries its best.

BE11:07am

Michalis Imellos, who has been CFO since 2012 and is considered a safe pair of hands, will continue to serve as acting CEO. Further announcements will be made in due course on who will become the permanent CEO.
In the near term, trading on 22.5x cal 2018 PE, a modest premium to European beverages on 21.9x, we would expect some share price volatility given that the stock has re-rated in part due to expectations on capital deployment.

11:07 am
undefined
BE11:08am

Following CCH down is WPP ......

WPP PLC (WPP:LSE): Last: 1,365, down 28 (-2.01%), High: 1,369, Low: 1,357, Volume: 4.52m
11:08 am
PM11:08am

There's a slow rot at WPP

BE11:09am

Well, it's post Morgan Stanley slotting a load overnight.

PM11:09am

THis was 16 quid last month

11:09 am
PM11:09am

Any sense of how much MOST sold?

BE11:09am

22.5m at 1,350p per share, accelerated bookbuild.

BE11:10am

Brief excitement last night when the term sheet went around, on the assumption that it was Sorrell.

11:10 am
PM11:10am

Now that would be a sell signal

BE11:10am

But, nope. It was Morgan Stanley being sole bookrunner for Morgan Stanley. Not sure how they book the fees on that.

PM11:11am

Sorrell's got to do some proper 'estate planning' at some point

11:11 am
PM11:11am

I mean, how old is he now?

PM11:11am

Into his 70s I'm pretty sure

BE11:12am

Yes, something like that.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Anyway, the other bit of WPP news is Bain Capital buying Asatsu

BE11:12am

For $1.3bn

PM11:12am

Asatsu of Japan

11:12 am
BE11:12am

That's the one .... which is interesting for a number of reasons, the first being that PE's getting involved in ad agencies.

BE11:13am

There's been loads of speculation around recently about the future of integrated agencies, and whether companies like Accenture or whatever might be interested in yomping into the ad space.

BE11:14am

The sidebar is that WPP owns 25% of Asatsu, so $320m or thereabouts.

11:14 am
PM11:15am

The idea of accountants/consultants moving into advertising feels kinda toppy to me.

PM11:15am

I mean, why?

BE11:15am

I guess it shows the trust deficit in advertising when it's a plausible idea that consultancies might be better able to sell inventory.

11:15 am
PM11:15am

Suppose there are synergies in opacity

BE11:15am

Anyway, have Exane on the theory.

BE11:16am

We note that Asatsu shares have materially outperformed larger global holding agency peers in the past 6 and 12 months. This could suggest some corporate action was already expected. Despite the 15% premium and strong share price run, the FY2017 acquisition multiple of Asatsu is c8.1x EBITDA and 1.15x EV/Sales using consensus. This is a discount to larger hold co agencies and significantly less than our first take suggested as one needs to account for the cJPY75bn+ value of stakes held by Asatsu (of which cJPY65bn is the WPP stake). It compares to a stated Bloomberg EV of JPY130bn at deal value that doesn’t adjust for investments held by Asatsu.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

In the long run, Corporate action is more likely to be driven by convergence than PE The scale, higher multiple, higher margin and greater complexity of the top holding companies makes any PE deal much more difficult to achieve than for the Asatsu deal. We see it as more likely that IT/Consulting groups could be interested in joining forces with ad agencies in the mid- term to catch up with the likes of Accenture (which we don't see as an acquirer).

BE11:17am

Oh, and a third reason on WPP .... I think there's a trade press report around that they've lost AB Inbev as a client.

BE11:17am

Though I haven't seen it yet.

11:17 am
PM11:18am

Blimey, that would be a blow

BE11:18am

Is that enough ad agencies or do we want Kepler on the sector as well?

PM11:18am

Just note the ABI story

11:18 am
PM11:18am

http://adage.com/a...dia-review/310702/

BE11:18am

.... Ah, ta.

BE11:19am

We may as well have Kepler on the sector. I can tell the ROTR are rapt.

11:18 am
PM11:19am

Dentsu Aegis Network has emerged as the big winner in Anheuser-Busch InBev's global media agency review, with its Vizeum agency taking over media planning and buying duties in the U.S. from WPP's MediaCom. Vizeum also won Canada, Europe and Africa, giving it the largest chunk of media duties for the world's largest brewer.

PM11:19am

Ok, do share Kepler

BE11:19am

The recent slowdown in organic growth has driven ad agencies to ten-year relative multiple lows. Although the escalation of cost-cutting in the biggest client sector, FMCG (25% of sales), and contractual adjustments in media following 2016’s highly critical ANA report on transparency look like multi-
year pressures, the short tenure of CMOs (42 months on average) means that client adjustments in marketing tend to be fast. This could indicate an easing of headwinds by the start of 2018, a more favourable year calendar-wise for advertising (mini-quadrennial), which could also be helped by belated
corporate and personal taxes in the US, one-third of the global ad market.
Publicis is already starting to show that consulting contracts can offset
pressure on traditional activities, while a series of recent bumper media wins
could reverse momentum for WPP in 2018.

11:19 am
PM11:19am

I can't see the ROTR -- comments not streaming for me.

BE11:20am

Our analysis suggests that the current pressure on agency growth is more the
confluence of a perfect storm of negatives than a broken model:

Advertising & Promotion (A&P) spend as a percentage of sales has not
declined for the FMCG sector over the past five years.
Shareholder activists, the apparent source of cost-cutting pressure in
FMCG, want more product innovation to increase organic growth
rather than management to commit the cardinal error of cutting ad
spend.
Consultants have not yet convinced even disgruntled ad clients that
they are a viable alternative for traditional agency activities.
Publicis, through Sapient, is the only agency with a presence in wider
business transformation consulting. Although far from consultants in
terms of market share, it has the opportunity to participate in the
segment’s expected 15-20% CAGR through to 2022.
The percentage of spend on Facebook/Google platforms through
traditional agencies seems to be keeping pace with the latter’s growth.
The ad spend intensity of disrupters is higher than incumbents’.

PM11:20am

Which makes this job even more difficult

11:20 am
BE11:20am

...... let's push on regardless.

undefined
PM11:20am

Anglo American

11:20 am
PM11:21am

I was in a room recently with 'someone close" to AA

BE11:21am

Oh yes?

PM11:21am

And I asked the pointed question

11:21 am
PM11:21am

And got a straight: "I'm not at liberty to discuss client affairs."

PM11:21am

But it was the way it was delivered

PM11:22am

It was blunt

11:21 am
PM11:22am

In a STFU sort of way

PM11:22am

All i could do was smile in response

BE11:23am

Hm. It's an open secret of sorts that Agarwal is working on something.

11:23 am
BE11:24am

We've no clarity on exactly what that something is, but he's not bought 20% of Anglo (in a fiendishly tricky structure) because he's bullish on Q4 diamond demand.

PM11:24am

If someone -- Agarwal or whoever -- is to move on Anglo is would be such a bid on South Africa coming right.

PM11:24am

And right now it's still in turmoil

11:24 am
PM11:24am

Big ANC thing in December, yeah?

PM11:25am

Need to see who takes over from Zuma

BE11:25am

.... Though Agarwal's relationship with SA politics is another interesting twist here.

11:25 am
BE11:26am

Previous assumptions were around Anglo separating out South Africa to get a non-discounted valuation on the rest.

BE11:27am

Agarwal's involvement makes it equally plausible that it'd be copper that'd be sold off, long term, as that's the bit that doesn't really fit in the (entirely theoretical, please note) Vedanta-Anglo diversified champion model.

BE11:27am

I recommend once more to read Neil on the possibilities here: https://www.ft.com...-9a86-4d5a475ba4c5

11:27 am
BE11:28am

Anyway, why they're up is nothing to do with this.

PM11:28am

Thumbs up

BE11:28am

It's HSBC pushing.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Mark to market for the sector, Anglo looks cheapish.

PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

BE11:29am

Cash flow and balance sheets strong; all companies paying dividends: Net debt has reduced to the lowest levels in years and should reduce further as all companies tightly manage their balance sheets and resist M&A (GLEN the exception). Forward dividend yields are forecast to average c5% (range is 3-6%) before including special dividends and/or share buybacks. RIO has just announced a further USD2.5bn share buyback and while AAL and GLEN are unlikely to supplement their ordinary dividend in the near term, BHP will be in a position to consider such shortly.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

So how should these companies be valued? With muted production growth for the key commodities (typically 1-2%pa), there is no longer a growth story for the large miners. While there may be some opportunity to further cut costs and/or improve productivities, the low hanging fruit has been picked and this is unlikely to move the dial in the short term. So, in our opinion, it comes down to three catalysts for earnings growth/rerating: (1) being in the “right” commodities; (2) distributing surplus cash; and (3) being positioned for value-adding M&A or corporate restructuring. On the first point, we have a distinct preference for Base Metals over Bulks, which favours
GLEN; on the second point, BHP and RIO are best positioned to raise distributions to shareholders in the near term although in the medium term all companies are well positioned and lastly, AAL is the only potential corporate play of the four companies and is the most likely to restructure in a significant way due to the imposts of its SA asset base and only GLEN appears to have the appetite for opportunistic M&A.

BAE Systems PLC (BA.:LSE): Last: 621.33, down 9.17 (-1.46%), High: 624.50, Low: 613.00, Volume: 4.73m
BE11:36am

Berenberg downgrade following a management meeting.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Plus a bit of rethinking on contract timing

BE11:37am

Which leads them to forecast "no organic revenue growth and modest earnings progression in the next two years".

BE11:37am

Typhoon production rate dampens near-term outlook: In the absence of a
firm export order materialising for the Typhoon programme, we now forecast FY 2018/19 delivery rates falling c50% yoy from 20 in 2017 to 11
and five aircraft respectively. This may result in a further slowdown of delivery rates which could generate negative sentiment around BAE’s largest franchise programme. On our revised estimates, we anticipate FY 2018/19 revenue and profit headwinds of 4% yoy (£700m/£70m respectively). Despite the anticipated ramp-up of franchise programmes within the existing backlog (F-35, MBDA, and a number of US land vehicle programmes), the phasing will not offset the near-term Typhoon headwinds in FY 2018 and FY 2019. If no further Typhoon export orders are secured within the next 12 months, we see a further 3% EPS headwind in FY 2020, although this is outside of our current forecast.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Then you have the pension deficit, and the fact that the gilt curve is up 50% since its last 3ennial.

BE11:38am

Which was 2014.

BE11:39am

We anticipate an output valuing the actuarial deficit at £4bn (an increase of 35% from £2.6bn in FY 2014), and have modelled an incremental £125m pa for the cash recovery plan, to a run rate of £400m. We expect the conclusion of the pension review by the end of the year.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

....... so .................

BE11:39am

We cut our FY 2017/18/19 EPS by 1%/6%/10% respectively to reflect the lack of organic growth over the next two years, principally driven by the step-down in our Typhoon production forecast, and weakness in the Applied Intelligence and US ship repair businesses.
● Valuation: Our blended average of FY 2018/19 SOTP generates a price target of 600p. The stock currently trades on an FY 2019 EV/EBIT multiple of 13x, at a 10% discount to US peers. In our view, this looks fully valued at present given the near-term outlook.

PM11:40am

(WMD -- link?)

11:41 am

(@Boycott: if I remember correctly, they'd have to transfer to AIM then hope he doesn't shuffle off within two years of the move, then also hope the HMRC doesn't see this as blatant tax avoidance and decide it is in fact a regulated investment. Bit tricky, all in all.)

BE11:45am

BE11:45am

Current trading looks a bit of a slowdown, at 6% LFL from 8% in the Q4.

11:45 am
BE11:46am

But guidance is unchanged.

BE11:46am

Oh, and it's changing reporting currency to dollars.

BE11:46am

In advance of switching its primary listing to the US, which will surely happen at some point in the future.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Peel Hunt is readable.

BE11:47am

Robust results from Wolseley, sorry Ferguson, saw the group post FX boosted revenue growth of 23% and profit growth of 25%. Trading in the new year has started well, with organic growth of over 6% led by the US residential and commercial markets. With the US now accounting for nearly 90% of ongoing group profits, the name change and shift to US$ reporting, we continue to expect a shift in listing to the US, which will see the shares more favourably compared with higher rated US peers. Hold.

BE11:48am

Performance & valuation. The shares have been fairly flat ytd (-2%) after
bouncing back c10% in the last month. In valuation terms, they are trading on a PE of c15x and 10x EV/EBITDA for July 2018, with a dividend yield of c2.6%. We see the shares trading a little better today, but not moving on materially. The bigger call comes from our view that the shares will see its primary listing shift to the US, and comparisons more readily made with the higher rated US peers (WW Grainger, Fastneal, Watsco Home Depot, Lowes).

11:48 am
BE11:48am

And Citi.

BE11:48am

We expect consensus to be well supported on the back of solid
underlying growth in the US, though bottom end estimates are likely to edge up. Stock continues to look good value trading on a 2018e EV/EBITDA of c.10x and offers a D/Y of +6.6% (incl. share buyback of £500m).

PM11:48am

This company really should have kept its original name. Imagine what the rating would be now if it had.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

?

PM11:48am

The Wolseley Sheep Shearing Machine Company Limited

PM11:49am

https://en.wikiped...ng_Machine_Company

11:48 am

Really? That's a thing.

PM11:49am

Frederick York Wolseley (16 March 1837 – 8 January 1899) was an Irish-born New South Wales inventor and woolgrower who invented and developed the first commercially successful sheep shearing machinery after extensive experimentation.[1] It revolutionised the wool industry.

BE11:49am

Hm. Staying true to your heritage did no harm to Wire and Plastic Products.

11:50 am
undefined
BE11:52am

(@Paper Chase: honestly, if we had anything to say we'd say it. Right now, at this exact moment, we don't. And my point in brackets earlier about Glaxo is a broad observation rather than a stock-specific one.)

BE11:53am

.... spinning back through comments, some requests for Imperial Brands.

11:53 am
Imperial Brands PLC (IMB:LSE): Last: 3,171, up 4.5 (+0.14%), High: 3,186, Low: 3,152, Volume: 543.68k
BE11:54am

Not entirely sure why. Forecasts have budged down a bit post the trading update suggesting 2018 wound be another investment year.

BE11:54am

In terms of the sector we've also got the Altria-Reynolds case settlement after a mere 18 years.

11:54 am
PM11:55am

Blimey

PM11:55am

Really?

BE11:55am

Yep. We'll be getting publish “corrective statements” across TV, newspapers, websites and cigarette packs for a year or more to tell the world that gaspers aren't a health food.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Will it make any difference to BAT volumes? Well, probably not. And Imperial's not even involved in the litigation so the difference will be less than nothing.

BE11:56am

Have Citi.

BE11:57am

We think this shows that U.S. (litigation) risk is diminished, not increased – Since July, when the FDA said it is considering lowering nicotine in cigarettes to non-addictive levels, many investors have told us that risk in U.S. tobacco has increased. The outcome of the DoJ isn’t a surprise, but we do think it demonstrates once again that the risk around U.S. litigation has become immaterial. This news disposes off one of the major legacy cases. The Engle cases rumble on, but the payouts are small and the case load is finite and diminishing. No other cases in the U.S. concern us. We are worried by Canadian litigation, but that is another matter.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

The statements are extremely wordy, TBF, and are unlikely to be news to anyone who's not been under a rock for 50 years.

BE11:59am

Complete text, in screenshot form to save on dull grey.

BE11:59am

11:59 am
BE11:59am

BE12:00pm

Something to read while you're standing in the car park, I guess.

BE12:00pm

Back to Citi.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

he DoJ was one of the scariest cases in tobacco – The U.S. Department of
Justice filed the case back in 1999, demanding compensation for healthcare costs as it said the companies had misled consumers about the health consequences of
smoking over four decades and marketed cigarettes to children. In 2005 the trial court ruled in favor of the government, ruling that industry had to “disgorge” $280 billion of ill-gotten profits. However, higher courts simultaneously said that
disgorgement wasn’t appropriate in this case. In 2006, the trial court ruled that even if there was no financial compensation for healthcare costs, the industry (1) had to stop making misleading statements about cigarettes; and (2) had to publish
corrective statements, highlighting the risks of smoking and saying that the
companies designed cigarettes to make them more addictive. In the following 11 years, the industry has been litigating over aspects of the corrective statements, and it is only now, 18 years after the start of the case, that the parties have agreed on all the issues.

BE12:01pm

All of which is wildly irrelevant. Have RBC on Imps instead.

BE12:01pm

Market share gains in H2 reassure us that the good stuff Imperial is doing to fix its volume trend is starting to have the intended results, notwithstanding the unwelcomed contribution of the one-off pension restructuring. Meanwhile, we think concerns over the sustainability of Imperial's dividend and Investment Grade credit rating are overdone.

12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

The fact that the pension restructuring is instrumental to be "on track to meet earnings expectations for the full year" is not what we hoped to hear in Imperial's pre-close statement. On the other hand, the market share gains flagged by the company in H2 reassure us that the good stuff Imperial is doing to fix its volume trend (brand migrations, SKU reduction and increased investments) is starting to have the intended results.

Meanwhile, we expect Imperial's generous dividend policy to continue to be supportive in the medium term. In our base case (EPS CAGR of 4.6% over the next ten years) we expect Imperial to be able to sustain the current dividend policy of +10% p.a. for 7-8 years before the payout ratio exceeds 90%, implying a distribution of around 50% of the company's current market cap. Assuming a volume shortfall of 1.5% and 3% implies the current dividend policy would be sustainable for 5-6 years.

As for the credit rating, we think the evolution of Imperial's Debt/EBITDA would be consistent with Moody's criteria for Investment Grade both under our base case and assuming a volume shortfall of 1.5% (3.5x in FY18E and FY19E respectively). As for RCF/Net Debt, we don't think it will become compatible with an Investment Grade rating in the short-term, although it is very unlikely it can trigger a downgrade alone, given that the low level is merely a function of the high dividend paid. Assuming a volume shortfall of 3% would push the two metrics in "danger zone" but, even in this case a downgrade would be far from granted given that Leverage and Coverage ratios carry a weight of only 36% on the final rating vs other more qualitative factors making up for the difference.

BE12:02pm

There. That's probably enough for a stock that's not moved on no news.

12:07 pm

And Paul's in the fifth circle of BOFH right now, so it's up to me to wish you a good afternoon, thank you and go away.

BE12:08pm

Good afternoon, thank you and go away. Back tomorrow.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Earnings still on the rise for all companies: While six monthly earnings for all companies were higher, this was far from a stellar performance. Except for AAL, production volumes were down and weaker than expected. BHP and RIO’s production were both cut by the Escondida strike; the former also saw shale volumes continuing to fall while the latter’s iron ore production missed guidance. GLEN had the worst half-year, battling on all fronts. As most commodity prices have
strengthened and production volumes are guided to be stronger, 2H17 earnings for all companies are again likely to be stronger than 1H17.
